item.title: Witnesses Recount Fire That Killed 40 in Switzerland
item.description: It was a haven for the young, where they could find hot chocolate when they wanted quiet and affordable drinks when they did not. Then it turned into a place of death.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic and Til Bürgy
item.media:credit: Til Bürgy for The New York Times

item.title: Swiss Authorities Say Sparklers Probably Caused New Year’s Fire
item.description: An official said the sparklers were attached to bottles of champagne held too close to the ceiling. Forty people died and more than 100 were injured. Many of the victims were teenagers.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Til Bürgy for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Says U.S. Will Intervene if Iran Kills Protesters
item.description: Mr. Trump’s remarks that he was ready to come to the protesters’ “rescue” are a sharp escalation as protests over economic hardship turned deadly.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir, Sanam Mahoozi and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:credit: Fars News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Shopkeepers and traders protesting in Tehran on Monday in a state media handout photo.

item.title: Yemen Sends Its Military to Push Out Separatist Faction
item.description: The Saudi-backed government in Yemen said it would send forces to reclaim territory from a group that the United Arab Emirates supports.
item.dc:creator: Ismaeel Naar
item.media:description: Soldiers affiliated with the Southern Transitional Council separatist group, which has seized control of parts of Yemen, at a checkpoint in Aden on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Zelensky Names Kyrylo Budanov as New Chief of Staff
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky said that in addition to that appointment, he planned to name a new defense minister as part of “a wave of personnel changes.”
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kyrylo Budanov, one of Ukraine’s highest-profile generals, has been asked to move into a political role.

item.title: In China, A.I. Finds Pancreatic Cancer That Doctors May Miss
item.description: A tool for spotting pancreatic cancer in routine CT scans has had promising results, one example of how China is racing to apply A.I. to medicine’s tough problems.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Andrea Verdelli
item.media:description: Self-service kiosks at the Affiliated People’s Hospital of Ningbo University. The hospital, in Ningbo, China, is testing an A.I.-powered tool for detecting pancreatic cancer.

item.title: Why a Nuclear Plant Is a Big Sticking Point in the Ukraine Peace Plan
item.description: The Zaporizhzhia plant, occupied by Russia, would be crucial to powering Ukraine’s postwar recovery.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, along the banks of the Dnipro River, in 2022.

item.title: Venezuela Frees Dozens of Political Prisoners
item.description: At least 80 people were released, including one with U.S. ties, though more than 800 remain detained in Venezuela for opposing President Nicolás Maduro’s rule, rights groups say.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Annie Correal
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of women holding handkerchiefs with the names of political prisoners in Caracas in November.

item.title: Guinea’s Coup Leader Wins Election After Barring Leading Opponents
item.description: Gen. Mamady Doumbouya, who seized power more than four years ago, took over 80 percent of the vote, according to a government-controlled agency that he set up.
item.dc:creator: Saikou Jammeh
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Gen. Mamady Doumbouya of Guinea during his final campaign rally in Conakry last week.

item.title: Another New Year at War: Ukraine’s Troops Doubt It Will Be the Last
item.description: After a year of Russian advances, the goal for 2026 is simply to survive, said one officer in eastern Ukraine. “It’s hard to make any plans,” he said.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Oleksandr Chubko
item.media:description: A Ukrainian serviceman of the Da Vinci Wolves Battalion carrying an artillery shell before firing toward Russian positions at the front line in eastern Ukraine, in November.

item.title: A Monumental Church in Amsterdam Is Ravaged by Flames on New Year’s Day
item.description: Local residents were evacuated after a fire broke out at the Vondelkerk shortly after midnight. The cause of the blaze has not yet been confirmed.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Koen Van Weel/ANP, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Vondelkerk on New Year’s Day, after the blaze had been extinguished.

item.title: How Two Powerful U.S. Allies Came to Blows in Yemen
item.description: Tensions between Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates burst into the open this week with an unusually direct confrontation that has global implications.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: Burned-out vehicles at Al Mukalla port, in southern Yemen, on Tuesday after an early-morning strike by a Saudi-led coalition.

item.title: Explosions Reported in Venezuela’s Capital
item.description: It was not immediately clear what caused the blasts. The United States has been building pressure on Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela’s authoritarian president, for months.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Smoke rising near La Carlota airport after explosions and low-flying aircraft were heard in Caracas, Venezuela, on Saturday.

item.title: Swiss Bar Fire Likely Caused By Sparklers, Authorities Say
item.description: Fireworks attached to bottles of Champagne sent up showers of sparks that appear to have ignited insulation in a bar. The blaze killed 40 people.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic, Aurelien Breeden and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial outside the Constellation bar in Crans-Montana, Switzerland, on Friday, the day after 40 people died there in a fire.

item.title: Oil Tanker Fleeing U.S. Coast Guard Broadcasts Location in North Atlantic
item.description: Russia requested this week that the United States end its pursuit of the vessel, which was intercepted in the Caribbean on its way to pick up oil in Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert and Nicholas Nehamas
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The oil tanker Bella 1, photographed in March. It recently appeared in Russia’s official register of ships under a new name, the Marinera.

item.title: A Rescuer Recounts How He Saved Lives During Swiss Bar Resort Fire
item.description: Nestor Fischer, 17, forced open a blocked door at Le Constellation, the Swiss bar that caught fire on New Year’s Day
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Til Bürgy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Authorities shielded Le Constellation bar and lounge on Friday to conduct an investigation following the deadly fire on New Year’s Day.

item.title: Families search for information about those unaccounted for.
item.description: Desperate families are searching for news about their missing children and loved ones, more than a day and a half after the inferno at a bar.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Til Bürgy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mementos left near Le Constellation bar in Crans-Montana, Switzerland, where dozens remain missing after a New Year’s Day fire.

item.title: China’s BYD Surpasses Tesla as World Leader in Electric Car Sales
item.description: As the largest maker of electric vehicles in the United States, Tesla suffered more than other carmakers from the elimination of federal incentives.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:description: Tesla’s decreasing sales suggest that a wider slump is in store for electric vehicles.

item.title: Survivor Recounts Moment He Caught Fire in Swiss Bar
item.description: Noa Bersier went to Le Constellation with friends on a whim. An hour later, he was caught in one of Switzerland’s worst tragedies.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside the sealed-off Le Constellation bar on Friday.

item.title: Swiss Authorities Face the Grim Task of Identifying Fire Victims
item.description: Identifying the victims of a New Year’s fire in Crans-Montana that killed more than 40 people could take days or weeks because of the severity of the burns.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross, Elisabetta Povoledo and Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:description: A medical helicopter landing next to air ambulance planes at the Sion airport in Switzerland on Friday. Victims are being treated in several hospitals in Switzerland and neighborhing countries.

item.title: Le Constellation, Swiss Bar Where Fire Hit, Was Popular With Young People
item.description: More affordable prices and the lack of an entrance fee made the bar an attractive alternative to more upmarket establishments.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Til Bürgy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Le Constellation had an upstairs and downstairs area, and was frequented by a younger crowd.

item.title: There Was Probably a Flashover in the Swiss Bar Fire. Here’s What That Means.
item.description: A flashover is an event where an entire room is rapidly engulfed in flames.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Til Bürgy for The New York Times
item.media:description: The authorities said that a flashover had likely happened at Le Constellation, the bar in Crans-Montana, Switzerland.

item.title: Swiss Resort Bar Fire: 17-Year-Old Italian Golfer Is One of the First Identified Victims
item.description: Mr. Galeppini, 17, was a promising young golfer from Genoa who lived in Dubai with his family, the Italian media reported.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Til Bürgy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Flowers near the bar Le Constellation in Crans-Montana, Switzerland, on Friday.

item.title: In the Arctic, Drones Help Identify Deadly Virus in Whales
item.description: Scientists took samples from whale blow, identifying possible disease risks for marine mammals in northern seas.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil

item.title: Brenna Henn Wanted to Improve Genetic Medicine. Then Her N.I.H. Grant Was Cut.
item.description: Brenna Henn had a long-term grant to study the genetic diversity of Africans and people of African descent. Then her N.I.H. funding was cut.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:credit: Andri Tambunan for The New York Times

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic, Amelia Nierenberg, Jenny Gross and Aurelien Breeden

item.title: Can F.C. Barcelona, the Most Indebted Team in Global Soccer, Fix Its Finances?
item.description: F.C. Barcelona’s liabilities have reached 2.5 billion euros, the result of financial mismanagement and vaulting ambition.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: The Camp Nou stadium in Barcelona, Spain, reopened in November, which is mostly related to a stadium refurbishment.

item.title: Search Is Suspended for Passenger Who Went Overboard From Cruise Ship
item.description: The U.S. Coast Guard said on Thursday that it halted its hourslong search for a 77-year-old woman who went overboard from a Holland America Line cruise ship near Cuba.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: The Holland America Line cruise ship Nieuw Statendam in Portland, in southwest England, in 2024. A 77-year-old woman went overboard from the ship as it was cruising near Cuba on Thursday.

item.title: Switzerland’s Burn Centers Are Overwhelmed After New Year’s Fire
item.description: Transfers of patients to hospitals in Germany, Italy and France began on Thursday. France said on Friday that 11 injury victims would be hospitalized there.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:description: An air ambulance leaving the main hospital in Sion, Switzerland, the closest to the deadly fire, on Thursday.

item.title: A Deadly Blaze in Switzerland
item.description: Plus, tips from our readers on how to stay informed without feeling overwhelmed in 2026.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Til Bürgy for The New York Times
item.media:description: A makeshift memorial in Crans-Montana, Switzerland.

item.title: Fire in Swiss Alps Leaves Dozens of New Year’s Revelers Dead
item.description: About 40 people celebrating at a ski resort bar were killed, and 115 were injured, many of them young, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic, Christopher F. Schuetze, Aurelien Breeden and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:credit: Til Bürgy for The New York Times
item.media:description: An officer near a bar in Crans-Montana, Switzerland, where a deadly fire broke out during a New Year’s celebration early Thursday.

item.title: Bars, nightclubs and discos have been the sites of deadly fires.
item.description: Over
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:credit: Til Bürgy for The New York Times
item.media:description: An informal memorial for the victims of the deadly fire at a bar in Crans-Montana, a ski resort town in southern Switzerland, on Thursday.

item.title: Survivors of Swiss Fire Search for News of the Victims
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:description: A view of the main hospital in Sion, Switzerland, which was inundated with victims of a deadly fire on Thursday.

item.title: What to Know About the Swiss Ski Resort Fire on New Year’s Day
item.description: A fast-moving fire at a bar in a popular ski resort killed 40 people and injured 119, officials said. Sparklers atop champagne bottles probably caused the fire.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Alessandro Della Valle/Keystone, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Dozens of people were killed, and more than 100 others were injured, after a fire broke out early New Year’s Day at Le Constellation, a bar in Crans-Montana, Switzerland, the authorities said.

item.title: Iran Protests Turn Deadly as Violence and Anger Spread
item.description: Financial pressures have fueled a fifth day of demonstrations around Iran, with at least one person killed in the protests so far, according to the authorities.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Sanam Mahoozi and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:credit: Majid Asgaripour/Wana News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: A photo released by Iranian state media showed shops closed in Tehran’s Grand Bazaar on Tuesday, following protests over a currency crisis.

item.title: Russia Asks United States to Stop Pursuit of Fleeing Oil Tanker
item.description: The tanker, which had been sailing to Venezuela to pick up oil, has claimed Russian protection, although the U.S. authorities say it is a stateless vessel.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Nehamas, Edward Wong and Tyler Pager
item.media:description: A U.S. Coast Guard helicopter flying in Puerto Rico last month.

item.title: Crans-Montana Bar Fire Victims Transported Across Switzerland for Treatment
item.description: Patients were taken by helicopter and jet to bigger, specialized hospitals in Geneva, Zurich and Lausanne.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Hospital du Valais in Sion, Switzerland, quickly filled up with victims of the fire.

item.title: Crans-Montana is a Historic Swiss Ski Resort Town Popular With International Tourists
item.description: The town is known for its gourmet food and luxury stores, and for hosting major sporting events. The Crans-Montana Resort, which does not operate the bar that caught fire, was acquired by Vail Resorts in 2024.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Alessandro Della Valle/Keystone, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Police officers investigate the area where the fire at Le Constellation bar broke out in Crans-Montana, a popular ski resort town in Switzerland.

item.title: Here is the latest.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze, Aurelien Breeden and John Yoon

item.title: Suicide Bomber in Syria Kills Security Officer in New Year’s Eve Attack
item.description: The attacker likely had links to the Islamic State and was possibly targeting a Christian church in the center of Aleppo, according to a government spokesman.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni and Hussam Hammoud
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: A view of Aleppo, Syria, where a suicide bomber struck on Wednesday.

item.title: Sabotage Suspected in Cutting of Undersea Cable, Finnish Police Say
item.description: The authorities seized the Fitburg, a cargo ship that was en route from Russia to Israel when it sliced the cable in the Gulf of Finland.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Johanna Lemola
item.media:description: The Fitburg, a 132-meter-long cargo ship, was anchored after being seized by the Finnish authorities in Kirkkonummi, Finland, on Wednesday.

item.title: Most of Iran Shuts Down as Government Grapples With Protests and Economy
item.description: Amid mounting street protests, businesses, universities and government offices stayed closed Wednesday under government orders, in 21 of 31 provinces, including Tehran.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni and Sanam Mahoozi
item.media:description: Tehran on Wednesday as businesses, universities and most government offices were told to close.

item.title: President Macron of France Backs Social Media Restrictions for Children
item.description: French lawmakers are expected next month to discuss a ban on social media for children. In his New Year’s Eve address, the French president restated his support for restricting their access.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France.

item.title: Venezuela Detains U.S. Citizens Amid Trump Administration’s Growing Pressure
item.description: The number of American citizens held in Venezuela has grown since the start of the U.S. military and economic campaign against President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Annie Correal and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela at a rally in Caracas, the capital, earlier this month.

item.title: Thieves Make Off With Millions in German Bank Heist
item.description: The robbers stole valuables with an insured value of at least $36 million from a bank in Gelsenkirchen, western Germany.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: The heist at first attracted little attention because the stolen contents were unclear.

item.title: In New Year’s Speech to Russia, Putin Says Little About Ukraine War or Peace Talks With US
item.description: The Kremlin leader kept his speech short, spoke only briefly about the fighting in Ukraine, and did not mention U.S.-mediated talks on ending the war.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Paul Sonne
item.media:description: In a photo distributed by Russian state media, President Vladimir V. Putin delivered his annual New Year’s Eve address in Moscow in 2024.

item.title: In Ukraine, an Arsenal of Killer A.I. Drones Is Being Born in War Against Russia
item.description: As the war grinds on, sophisticated Russian defenses have pushed Ukraine to develop a frightening new weapon: semiautonomous killing machines.
item.dc:creator: C.J. Chivers
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bumblebee attack drones at a combat testing range outside Kharkiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Ahead of New Year, Sydney Holds Vigil for Bondi Beach Attack Victims
item.description: Thousands gathered around the harbor to lift candles and phone lights during a minute of silence in solidarity with the Jewish community that was targeted in the attack.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

item.title: Mali and Burkina Faso Impose Travel Bans on Americans
item.description: The West African countries said they made the decisions in retaliation against the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Saikou Jammeh
item.media:description: Motorists drive through Bamako, Mali, in November. The government assailed the Trump administration’s decision to ban its citizens from traveling to the United States.

item.title: New Year’s 2026 Celebrations Around the World: Photos and Videos
item.description: See how people across the globe celebrated.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Confetti falling in Times Square.

item.title: Merz Says Relationship Between U.S. and Germany Is ‘Changing’
item.description: Chancellor Friedrich Merz of Germany, making his New Year’s Eve address, said the change would force Europe to do more to defend itself.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Mr. Merz’s speech followed signals from the Trump administration that it no longer sees Europe’s defense as a core American priority.

item.title: Bangladeshis Pay Last Respects to Former Leader in Tense Capital
item.description: Huge crowds turned out to say goodbye to Khaleda Zia, the country’s first female prime minister, amid a huge army presence following recent political violence.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Anupreeta Das
item.media:description: A supporter waves a flag bearing an image of Khaleda Zia, Bangladesh’s first female prime minister, during her funeral prayers outside the national Parliament building on Wednesday.

item.title: He Is Being Sued in the U.S. for Human Rights Abuses. He Could be Deported First.
item.description: Rafael Quero Silva faces a lawsuit brought by five people who say he oversaw their abuse and mistreatment as a military officer in Venezuela. But he could be deported before the case is heard.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: How Thousands of Secret Russian Documents Were Exposed
item.description: Russian journalists learned that a government office inadvertently made thousands of sensitive complaints viewable online, including accounts of abuse and coercion in the military.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Paul Sonne
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destroyed military vehicles at an abandoned Russian base in the town of Snihurivka in the Mykolaiv region of Ukraine.
